text:
S.H.

WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. George Pepper
Address: 219 Government Road, Wayburn
Birthplace: Stafford, Lincolnshire, England

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? June 17, 1914.
Where did you set up housekeeping? Homestead, Saskatchewan, Colgate NE 17-4-14 W2.
Where had you been living before that? England.
For how many people did you prepare meals? 6.
How far was it to your nearest store? Wayburn, Colgate.
How often could a visit be made to the store? 3 or 4 times a year.
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Just necessities, we fell off the year I load of wheat was hauled into Wayburn flour mills. We would take about 10 bags of flour so much bran, whole wheat, oat meal, and cream wheat.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? ........................................................

In what quantities did you buy it? ...........................................................................

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? It would be about $2.95.
How much did you use groat flour? 25 lbs.
Whole wheat flour? Wayburn, our flour from the mill at Wayburn.
Was flour milled locally? Yes.
How far away? 28 miles, what year? 1911.
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? About 40¢.
What other grain products did you use? ...............................................................
Cornmeal? Yes. Whole wheat? Yes. Farina? Yes.
Other? ..............................................................................................................

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? We put a little through coffee grinder enough for a meal at a time.
How did you grind it? .........................................................................................

What year did you start homesteading in eastern Canada? (Specify year.)

Where did you set up housekeeping? (Specify location.)

For how many years have you lived there? (Specify number of years.)

How far was it to your nearest store? (Specify distance.)

How often could a visit be made to the store? (Specify frequency.)

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? (Specify items.)

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years?

In what quantities did you buy it?

How much did you use each year?

Did you make your own flour?

Was the flour milled locally?

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?

What other grain products did you use?

Cornmeal? Yes.

Oats? Yes.

Did you grind your own wheat for flour?

How did you grind it?

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? ...........................................
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? ...........................................
What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? ...........................................
At what price? ...................................................................................

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? ...........................................
Did you make butter? ...........................................
What was the price of butter? ...........................................
Did you keep eggs for winter? ...........................................
Did you make butter? ...........................................
What kind of cheese? ...........................................

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? ...........................................
How did you get fresh meat? ...........................................
How often did you get fresh meat? ...........................................
How did you preserve meat? ...........................................
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? ...........................................
If so, what year was it organized? ...........................................
Did you use game? ...........................................
For how long? ...........................................
What part did fish play in the family diet? ...........................................
Kinds? White fish, salmon, trout, etc., for other purposes.

6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? .................. At what price? ..........
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) ..........
Price? .............................................. Other beverages used? ..........
How, where, and when did you buy them? ..........
Also coffee, tea, etc., because we had a lot of people in the house.

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

We used to buy vegetables at the store. Remember when we got them for 25 cents a bundle?

Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes, we wanted them.

If not, where from? All right, let's talk about preserving now.

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter? Our garden was good, but our garden was not very big.

Potatoes yes... Cabbage yes... Carrots yes... Onions yes...

Turnips yes... Beets yes... Radishes yes...

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? About 10 lbs.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? 25 cents each.

What weight? ........................................ How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? ...

Eat more fresh fruit, less canned. What was the price of prunes? Not very high.

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currents or others)?

A few.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Peas, corn, beans, Saskatoons?

Other foods? .........................................

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1920

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1920

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? Early years, about 1920

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Canning now...

To what extent? We can for our own use. We also put some food in the bottom.

Did you make your own vinegar? Yes, we used to make our own vinegar.

| Store jam - kinda?    |                 |                  |                          |                     |

Choose (Cheddar or store cheese) by the lb. I don't remember the prices.

Vanilla Rawleigh men use to round in a van on the Prairies. House wives would get quite a bit of medical supplies from them.

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal

Did you make yeast for your own use? Yes

Using starter? Yes

Using hops? No

Salt rising?

Did you buy baking powder? Yes

Baking soda? Yes

Cream of tartar? Yes

Did you make your own baking powder? No

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) We had a well about 20 ft deep above got water with driving a sand point, rainwater.

How far was this water from your home? ..............................................

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ..............................................

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. We came off the farm 1919 there was still Well Water then, some times in winter I have melted snow for house as well as stock during Blizzard.
12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Call, river, stream, dugout)

If so, how far was this water from your house?

Was it brought to the house? (Pull, barrel, tank)

If so, how was it brought?

If not, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started homesteading, giving dates where possible.

We were off the town '1919 there was still Well Water then as well as stock in winter I have milked cows for town as well as stock during Blizzard
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? If you made your own, did you use lye? Good soaps?

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Coarse brown soap used a lot.

14. FUEL

Soft coal

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Soft coal was about $0.50 per ton.

Where did you get your fuel? Miners at times.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you all began first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates)

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove made? Got it at Eaton's for $25.

What year was it purchased? 1915.

Price?

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Bought some from England when we came.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

When did you first see enamel ware? 1920.

Aluminum? 1922.
16. **SHOPPING AND CONTAINERS**

   Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

   In the early years we had peddlers come round. They would have all kinds of old overalls, smocks, shirts, etc. Buttons, thread, buttons, and just about everything that would be suitable to a housewife. Pubs kept these supplies. They would do a big turnover. The tea and coffee came from before we had very decorative ornaments practically to the house. Of course, Eaton and Simpson's Catalogues were the family book, so the old copy.

17. **Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.**

   We eat pretty well the same as now. Of course we had all our comforts to make our selves, our own Biscuits, Buns, Pies, Puddings, everything about the same only you had to do it yourself. We didn't have electricity, so we used oil lamps. We didn't stay up late at night unless neighbors came over. We were all kept busy making blankets. Building to really bubble round the stove when it was very cold, the houses then were built so very warm, one into the other would go out and back the house up with snow. But the times then people helped one another more, they were all poor, what it matters we would go with them to school house.

18. **What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?**

   Our first dinner on the Prairie was at one English London neighbor. They came out about 1900. We had chickens, potatoes, all kinds of vegetables and plum pudding with brandy sauce. And I remember the lady set fire to the brandy all blazing around the dish when she brought it in. Christmas was very special and Christmas Eve spent in church, pulled with oars and we sang songs to the school house for the Christmas Festival. Everybody was friendly all joining in the fun.

19. **Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.**

   Sometimes when blizzards or the roads were bad you got pretty low. I can remember when one of the children was very brought up on bottle, we had no milk for the bottle so we had to keep patching one bottle with another try to make it do till we could get some more. I lost one child in bad weather conditions.

   Our young hero doctor for 40 miles, yes we had our experiences of love standing but through all the hard times we can look back to some very happy times.

   We didn't see linoleum on the floors nor much paint on the floors or wood work, we got on our knees and crawled the floors, my first curtains were never hanging them out of these cloth I put fills around them and thought they looked the best. There was hardly houses you see curtains too. But it took a lot of patience to get along. We also sent to the mail order
Farmers for the oxen and afterwards we went in for horses. We had oxen about 3 years we paid $50 dollars each for the first horses we got 3 mares & horse, after that we started to improve. The three mares were in foal and it wasn't long before we got stock around. But we broke the homestead with Oseen. We see many prairie fires they would come so close it would make the walls of the old shack so hot. The women then played a big part, helping in raising stocking milking and many other things to numerous to mention. Neighbors were about 2 miles apart. We had an old Bachelor 1 mile away. I did his washing and baking, and we had another good neighbor, they built us close as they could to us we were on the edge of our land, & they were too. They had 4 children, so really it didn't seem to be lonely. In the evening the men folk would sit on the doorstep and play tunes on the mouth organ, something to drive the blues away.

Well I think I have told you a little of the life of the homesteading days. Afterwards my husband sold his homestead. He did carpentry work. Afterwards he helped to do building in Colgate & later Tribune.

Afterwards he was agent for Lumber yard in Tribune where he was from 1928 to 1958.

Now we are retired living in Waynoka.

Yours sincerely,

Mrs. Larry Pepper

The thing I noticed so much when I first came to the homestead was the noise of the frogs in the dews, a continual noise.
farmers for the oxen and afterwards we went in for horses. We had oxen about 3 years we paid $50 dollars each for the first horses we got 3 mares & horse, after that we started to improve. The three mares were in foal and it wasn't long before we got stock around. But we broke the homestead until Oscar. We see many Prairie fires they would come so close it would make the walls of the old stock so hot, the women then played a big part, helping in raising, stocking, milking and many other things to numerous to mention. Neighbors were about 2 miles apart, we had an old Bachelor 1 mile away. I did his washing and baking, and we had another good neighbor, they built as close as they could to us we were on the edge of our land, & they were too. They had 4 children, so really it didn't seem to be lonely. In the evening the men folk would sit on the doorstep and play tunes on the mouth organ, something to drive the blues away.

Well I think I have told you a little of the life of the homesteading days. Afterwards my husband sold his homestead, he did carpentry work, afterwards he helped to do building in Colgate & later Tribune, where he was from 1921 to 1958.

Now we are retired living in Wayburn.

Yours sincerely,

Mrs. George Pepper

The thing I noticed so much when I first came to the homestead was the noise of the frogs in the spring, a continual noise.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

The foods of today are all prepared, meats & fish etc used to be cut up in pieces and frozen, well that had to be brought in and thawed, and then some of the stores were not made for soft coal, some times houses were terrible cold, the fires wouldn't draw. I think the homesteaders relied on milk a deal more than they do now. Children took it with their meals more, children then to my idea eat more vegetables etc. Vegetables were few, potatoes were far apart.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homemade and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Late years Bread was on the markets all the time now. But then in homestead Bread & yeast was made by the housewife who was a busy woman looking after her household, no Power Washer lots of times no Washing Machine, sometimes no churns. I had a stock & Kneader, some times Butter would come quick & some times you would be hours getting Butter. We all had to try our hands in making the comfort for the families.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and acquiring foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

We would go to the store to buy our Butter & eggs and we would bring our groceries with what we got there. I can Remember taking eggs 6 cents a dozen, Butter 15 cents one summer. It was pretty hard sometimes to keep track of the days of the week. I have heard my husband say they were invited to one house for Easter Sunday they got there on a Saturday. I know when I went first before over there we use to set our clock by the sun at 12 o'clock the sun was direct in our kitchen Window. Throwing time was lots of work and lots of fun too. The meals would be big, you would rise early Porridge, meat & eggs to fry and sometimes Potatoes lots of work and sometimes the crops would be so poor and they would have everybody worrying as to how to send meet, there was no children.
